reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s handling of AI-assisted moral reflection in §2.3.1, which is relevant to (and partially supports) the paper’s broader pessimism about widespread accurate motivational convergence (WAM-convergence), but it’s not the linchpin of the overall position (other arguments—e.g., the metaethical argument in §2.4, blockers, threats/trade analysis—carry much of the weight). So centrality is moderate-low. Substantively, the critique claims the authors dismiss AI-assisted convergence primarily by motivation and fail to address whether superintelligence would yield convergent answers; but the paper explicitly does address the convergence question (it says superintelligent assistance doesn’t imply convergence because reflective starting points/processes can diverge) and then separately discusses motivation. So the critique only weakly undermines the targeted part, though it’s right that convergence and motivation are distinct and both matter. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and has little dead weight.
title: Dismissing superintelligent moral convergence conflates epistemic and motivational questions
